I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) has had devastating health, social, economic, and 
financial impacts across the world. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) estimates that the global 
output losses in 2020 can reach $4.1 trillion.1 On 13 April 2020, ADB announced a $20 billion 
package consisting of loans, grants, and technical assistance (TA) to help its developing member 
countries (DMCs) in Asia and the Pacific manage the wide-ranging consequences of COVID-19. 
As part of this package, ADB is working with several DMCs in Southeast Asia to formulate their 
immediate responses to COVID-19 and provide financial support for the health and fiscal stimulus 
requirements.2 The  proposed  regional  knowledge  and  support  TA  will  play  a  critical  and 
complementary role to ADB’s lending assistance in two ways.3  
 
2.  First, the TA will help the Southeast Asian DMCs that have received loans under ADB’s 
COVID-19 Pandemic Response Option (CPRO) and ADB to monitor the implementation of the 
COVID-19 response packages and provide updates to policy makers and stakeholders. The basis 
for this will be the Country Engagement Framework (CEF) prepared by ADB and tailored for each 
DMC as part of the relevant CPRO loan.4 Second, the TA will help Southeast Asian DMCs return 
to their pre-COVID-19 economic performance as quickly as possible. It will also help them be 
more prepared for any national, regional, or global transformation that may take place post-
COVID-19.  Specifically,  the  TA  will  lead  the  formulation  and  implementation  of  COVID-19 
recovery strategies, policies, and plans through in-depth analysis, stakeholder consultations, and 
high-level policy advice. Table 1 presents an illustrative set of issues that DMCs and countries 
around the world are grappling with, which will be covered under the TA. The timelines in Table 
1 are subject to change and ultimately will be determined by the epidemiological pathways of 
COVID-19 across the DMCs and elsewhere. 
 
3.  The TA is aligned with ADB’s comprehensive response to the COVID-19 pandemic.5 ADB 
has supported efforts to strengthen national and regional health systems through several TA 
projects and other projects. The TA will complement those initiatives by supporting DMCs’ efforts 
to bounce back their economies.6 The TA supports ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priorities of 
addressing poverty, reducing inequalities, accelerating progress on gender equality, and fostering 
regional cooperation and integration.7  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Flattening the pandemic curve and saving lives have been top priorities in all 
Southeast Asian countries (Phase 1, Table 1). To contain COVID-19, most countries have 
resorted to social distancing and large-scale community quarantine measures. All countries have 
also increased their budgetary allocations to the health sector and enacted emergency measures 
to set up COVID-19 treatment facilities supplemented by increased testing programs. ADB’s

5.  Flattening the recession curve has already become a major concern (Phase 2, Table 
1). In the short term of about 2-6 months after the onset of the pandemic, there is a clear trade-
off between flattening the pandemic curve and flattening the recession curve.9 While the world 
has not had a pandemic of this scale since the 1918 influenza pandemic, there is a common 
recognition that restarting economies may be much harder than shutting them down. In many 
countries, there are serious concerns that the severity of the economic decline may undo the 
gains made in poverty reduction, job creation, and infrastructure development. Many DMCs have 
risen to the challenge and have introduced large fiscal stimulus packages that acknowledge the 
different socioeconomic and health impacts experienced by men and women. The rapid response 
of ADB and other development partners will provide governments with some of the financial 
resources needed to mitigate the immediate impact of the COVID-19 outbreak (footnote 5). 
 
8  ADB. Indonesia: COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support Program (Project Number 54139) and ADB. 
Philippines: COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support Program (Project Number 54138). 
9  R. Baldwin and D.W. di Mauro. 2020. Mitigating the COVID Economic Crisis: Act Fast and Do Whatever It Takes. 
London.

3 
Alongside increases in health budgets, cash transfer programs are in place in many countries, 
recognizing the heightened risks of intergenerational poverty stemming from the COVID-19 
pandemic. Governments have provided enterprises with temporary liquidity support to maintain 
payrolls and partly compensate workers. Central banks and financial regulators have put in place 
supportive measures to ease the financial burden on micro, small and medium enterprises 
(MSMEs), large corporates, and banks. The private sector and philanthropic organizations have 
sprung to action to provide short-term relief. For the next 3–6 months, implementation of the policy 
responses must be carefully monitored in line with the CEFs in CPROs for COVID-19 response, 
particularly the measures adopted to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 on the poor and vulnerable, 
women, children, elderly, and people with disabilities. A TA project is also being prepared to 
respond to the gendered impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, including support for the heightened 
incidence of domestic and/or gender-based violence. 
 
6.  In parallel, countries need to plan for fuller recovery and near-term positioning 
(Phase 2, Phase 3, Table 1). Until the end of 2019, the Southeast Asian region had registered 
robust economic growth despite global uncertainties. However, the COVID-19 pandemic has 
drastically changed the economic outlook for all countries. The assessment of the International 
Monetary Fund’s chief economist is that the “Great Lockdown” will lead globally to the “worst 
economic downturn since the Great Depression.”10 Building on the wide-ranging measures taken 
by countries, the next phase must focus on helping the Southeast Asian economies bounce back 
toward full recovery. There is much debate about a V-shaped versus U-shaped recovery, with 
many betting on a V-shaped recovery. Yet, the experience of past crises suggests that business 
and consumer confidence and capital investment may take time to recover. Governments will 
need to step in with strong policy measures to restore confidence, without crowding out the private 
sector. Social protection may need to continue, while manufacturing, construction, and services 
sectors may need further support. The need and value of data have never been so critical as now. 
Many DMCs struggle with proper identification of poor and vulnerable households, including 
tracking the contribution of the informal sector, own-account workers, and unpaid family labor in 
overall economic output. The labor market participation of women and youth will be an important 
consideration for government and private sector skills training and financial support programs as 
governments seek to be rebuild their economies. Through careful design of policy packages, there 
is an opportunity to promote gender equality, unpack stereotypes affecting employment decision-
making, and break the cycle of intergenerational poverty across our DMCs.  
 
7.  The COVID-19 pandemic also has the potential to bring about transformational 
changes (Phase 3, Table 1). In addition to all these near-term considerations, COVID-19 will 
certainly usher in a “new normal.”11 One major concern in some DMCs is that 1–2 years of 
drastically slower growth may completely alter their aspirations for medium- to long-term growth 
and  prosperity.  In  general,  there  is  also  a  concern  about  the  speed  of  revival  of  capital 
expenditures,  particularly  for  infrastructure  development.  Another  factor  is  how  national 
sentiments and incentives will evolve partly as a reflection of the government’s response to the 
pandemic and a member’s position in the regional or global economic architecture. For instance, 
Southeast Asian DMCs have been quite well-integrated into regional and global value and supply

be tested in the coming months and possibly years. Governments that adopt a holistic and 
inclusive approach to supporting human capital development may empower men and women of 
all ages and abilities to engage in national socioeconomic recovery.  
 
8.  In this regard, a special dimension in the recovery process is the scope for regional 
cooperation and integration (RCI). Some of the long-standing RCI initiatives were born in the 
Southeast Asian region. That spirit of cooperation continues to remain strong. On 14 April 2020, 
the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) leaders had a virtual summit where they 
agreed to work together closely to combat COVID-19 and committed to collective actions to 
mitigate the economic and social impact of the crisis.12 It is critical to fully sustain the spirit of RCI 
in the recovery and any transformation process, and to continuously share information on national 
policy responses with a view to harmonizing them and facilitating learning. The national economic 
recovery  and  transformation  strategies  must  incorporate  emerging  regional  and  global 
imperatives and priorities. The Southeast Asian DMCs have much to gain by taking coordinated 
actions to ensure that adequate complementarities continue to exist among the economies.  
 
9.  On these fronts, timely and well-structured advice will be needed to guide the region’s 
policy makers to implement the necessary measures for economic recovery. Given the great 
diversity across the Southeast Asian economies, the recovery plans will have to be inclusive and 
tailored to the countries’ specific circumstances. A few crosscutting issues and themes will need 
to be incorporated into the assessments as well as the recovery and transformation strategies: 
(i)  alignment with a country’s own circumstances, priorities, aspirations, and needs; 
(ii)  protecting and strengthening the resilience of the poor and vulnerable, including 
women and children; 
(iii)  challenging gender-based stereotypes related to human capital development to 
maximize labor market participation for men and women in all sectors; 
(iv)  creating  positive  enabling  environments  for  good  governance,  private  sector 
participation, and RCI; 
(v)  incorporating  lessons  learned  from  the  COVID-19  pandemic,  while  reflecting 
readiness for other disasters and crises; 
(vi)  adequate regard for climate change, greening, and sustainability considerations; 
(vii)  learning good practices and approaches from other countries—either peers at the 
same level of development or more/less advanced countries; and 
(viii)  creating  avenues  for  partnerships  and  cooperation  (e.g.  between  countries, 
states/cities, and institutions) to strengthen preparedness for future challenges. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: Southeast Asian DMCs’ bounce back in their 
economic  performance to  pre-COVID-19  levels  achieved.13 The  TA  will  have  the following 
outcome: capacity of Southeast Asian DMCs to design and implement comprehensive policy 
responses to support inclusive economic recovery from the COVID-19 outbreak enhanced.14 The 
 
12 The ASEAN Secretariat. 2020. Declaration of the Special ASEAN Summit on Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-
19). https://asean.org/storage/2020/04/FINAL-Declaration-of-the-Special-ASEAN-Summit-on-COVID-19.pdf. 
13 ADB. 2020. ADB’s Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic. Manila; and ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: 
Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
14 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

5 
TA will focus on protecting the poor and vulnerable with due regard for gender considerations and 
promoting RCI. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: Support for effective implementation of CPRO loans provided. The TA will 
support the implementation of the CPRO loans, as well as guide DMCs in formulating forward-
looking plans. Both aspects of the TA will be coordinated by ADB, in close consultation with the 
governments. Tasks relating to the CEF will be supported by a team of individual consultants in 
each DMC with a CPRO loan. The CPRO monitoring will largely cover Phase 1 in Table 1 and  
will be closely aligned with the CEFs for each CPRO loan, with the main purpose of monitoring 
the inclusive implementation of the stimulus packages, undertaking private sector and civil society 
consultations, and assessing data quality and reliability to aid in key priorities such as social 
protection.  
 
12.  Output 2: Incisive assessments and analysis undertaken of the impact of COVID-19 
and the policy measures. This output will seek to understand the pathways of the COVID-19 
pandemic’s impact on the real, financial, and external sectors of selected Southeast Asian DMCs. 
While the approach and focus may vary across the DMCs, all assessments will include: (i) health 
and social aspects, with particular emphasis on the poor and vulnerable and due attention given 
to the specific gender impacts of COVID-19; (ii) the key economic drivers and principal sub-
sectors in each country, including consideration of labor market segmentation and how to support 
equitable and inclusive human capital development throughout the recovery phase; (iii) national, 
regional, and global value chain considerations; (iv) the role of MSMEs and large corporate 
entities; and (v) overall real-financial sector linkages. The assessments will also include a review 
of the existing support mechanisms and rapid response measures that were put in place by 
governments to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic. Examples include support to specific sectors 
(e.g.  tourism,  retail,  and  agriculture),  cash  transfers  to  poor  and  vulnerable  households, 
unemployment benefits, or tax benefits for MSMEs. Under the proposed TA, ADB will engage the 
services of a leading consulting firm or firms with expertise in formulating economic recovery or 
transformational plans to prepare the analyses and assessments related to this output. The 
consulting firm or firms will be requested to provide their services in a cost-effective manner. Their 
work will also contribute to output 4, with a supportive role for output 3.  
 
13.  Output 3: Policy consultations with senior officials held to guide the formulation of 
recovery and transformational strategies and plans. ADB will convene a high-level experts 
panel of globally well-known health experts, economists, social policy experts, and finance 
professionals to provide high-level advice to ministers and senior officials to guide the formulation 
of the recovery and transformational plans. ADB’s Vice-President for Operations Group 2 will 
convene the experts panel, with an ADB staff team acting as the secretariat. A number of high-
level consultative sessions will be organized by ADB, involving ministers, secretaries, senior 
officials, and the experts panel. The purpose of the consultations will be to guide the formulation 
of inclusive and equitable recovery strategies and plans. The panel may also articulate the types 
of transformational changes that may be triggered by the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic. 
The arrangements will be flexible, subject to the availability of the ministers and the experts panel. 
 
14.  Output 4: Recovery and transformational strategies and action plans formulated. 
There will be two sets of documents produced under output 4. First, based on the deliberations 
under output 3 and their expertise at global, regional, and national levels, a few selected members 
of the experts panel may be invited by ADB to draft advisory notes or papers and conduct 
presentations outlining their recommendations for the approaches that selected Southeast Asian

6 
countries, as well as the region, can adopt to navigate the post-COVID-19 world. The focus will 
be on the types of issues highlighted in Table 1 and paras. 4–7 (but not limited to those). 
Furthermore, depending on the expert’s focus, each member of the panel will also provide insights 
into his or her specialized area of expertise, while commenting on any other aspects of the 
recovery and transformation process. Indicative areas of specialized expertise are: (i) health 
policy;  (ii)  social  protection  for  poor  and  vulnerable  groups;  (iii)  unpacking  labor  market 
segmentation to maximize inclusive human capital development; (iv) value chains and trade; (v) 
corporate recovery and restructuring, and financial sector impact; (vi) support to MSMEs; (vii) 
fiscal policy; and (viii) big data and new technologies.  
 
15.  For the second set of documents produced under output 4, building on their work under 
output  2  and  deliberations  under  output  3,  the  consulting  firm  or  firms  will  produce  a 
comprehensive, inclusive, and equitable COVID-19 recovery bounce back strategy and action 
plan for selected countries. After consideration by the ADB team, the strategies and action plans 
will be shared with each government, as inputs to national strategies.  
 
16.  Output  5:  RCI  implications  and  knowledge  sharing  among  Southeast  Asian 
countries distilled. Under this output, ADB will engage the services of one or two  accomplished 
RCI experts to prepare a comprehensive paper examining the implications of COVID-19 for RCI 
and formulate and disseminate specific regional strategies on how to promote RCI for regional 
recovery and future resilience in Southeast Asia. The TA will also support policy forums at regional 
levels to present the results of the work done under outputs 1–4. Regional forums may include 
ASEAN+3 events, ASEAN Finance Ministers Forums, Greater Mekong Subregion, Indonesia-
Malaysia-Thailand Growth Triangle, and Brunei Darussalam-Indonesia-Malaysia-Philippines East 
ASEAN Growth Area ministerial meetings.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $5,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6 and TASF-other sources). ADB is also actively 
seeking grant cofinancing support from its development partners. The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 2. 
 
18.  Given the exceptional nature of the crisis, ADB will work together with globally recognized 
consulting firm or firms to provide their services in a highly cost-effective manner for the benefit 
of the countries affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The independent experts on the expert 
panel from academia and think tanks will be appropriately compensated for their services, which 
will include preparation of comprehensive papers outlining their views and policy advice. In 
addition,  ADB  will  recruit  several  international  and  national  experts  to  help  monitor  the 
implementation of the CPRO loans in selected DMCs. The governments may provide counterpart 
support in the form of staff time and other in-kind contributions related to data gathering.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
19.  ADB’s Southeast Asia Regional Department (SERD) will administer the TA, in close 
collaboration with the Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD); the 
Private  Sector  Operations  Department  (PSOD);  the  Strategy,  Policy  and  Partnerships 
Department (SPD); and the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC). 
These  departments  will  work  together  to  exchange  views,  knowledge,  and  information  on 
recovery strategies for COVID-19, including reviewing consultants’ outputs as needed. They will 
also nominate relevant staff to be team members for the TA. The selection of experts and

7 
consulting firm or firms will be coordinated by a team formed within SERD, in consultation with 
staff from the other departments.15 Resident missions in each country will play the key role in 
managing consultants under output 1 and consulting firm or firms in their respective countries.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1. Support for effective implementation of CPRO loans provided. 
1.1.  Collect data on the implementation and impacts of the policy packages included in the CPROs, with adequate 
focus on considerations relating to gender and the poor and vulnerable affected by the COVID-19 crisis  
(Q2 2020–Q4 2020). 
1.2.  Prepare a summary report of the deliberations in the main committee and the three subcommittees under the 
CPRO CEFs (Q4 2020–Q1 2021). 
1.3.  Share the information from the summary reports on ADB’s website under the heading: COVID-19 response in 
Southeast Asia, (Q2 2021–Q3 2021). 
 
2. Incisive assessments and analysis undertaken of the impact of COVID-19 and the policy measures. 
2.1  Collect data on the economic impacts of COVID-19 on businesses, households, and governments, with due 
consideration given to the socioeconomic recovery needs of women and men of all ages and abilities, and other 
poor and vulnerable groups (e.g. ethnic groups) (Q2 2020–Q4 2020).  
2.2  Work together with Southeast Asian governments to identify key impacts to the economy from the COVID-19 
outbreak (Q3 2020–Q1 2021). 
2.3 Review experiences, lessons learned, and good practices from policy responses to COVID-19 in Southeast 
Asian countries and in other regions (Q4 2020–Q1 2021). 
2.4 Prepare analytical assessments of existing and planned national policy packages to support an inclusive and 
equitable economic recovery (Q1 2021–Q2 2021).

Appendix 1  11 
3. Policy consultations with senior officials held to guide the formulation of recovery and transformational 
strategies and plans. 
3.1  Organize high-level consultation meetings with ministers and senior government officials in close consultation 
with government and other stakeholders (Q3 2020–Q2 2021). 
 
4. Recovery and transformational strategies and action plans formulated. 
4.1  Formulate inclusive and equitable national strategies and action plans for each CPRO country with clear 
considerations given to the socioeconomic recovery needs of women and men of all ages and abilities, and 
other poor and vulnerable groups (e.g. ethnic groups) (Q2 2020–Q4 2020). 
4.2  Organize national policy forums to discuss recovery strategies and action plans (Q4 2020–Q4 2021).  
 
5. RCI implications and knowledge sharing among Southeast Asian countries distilled. 
5.1. Formulate inclusive RCI initiatives on implications for RCI of the COVID-19 crisis on the Southeast Asian region 
(Q2 2020–Q4 2020)  
5.2. Organize 3 regional policy forums to discuss inclusive regional initiatives to support economic recovery in 
Southeast Asia. (Q4 2020–Q4 2021). 
5.3. Publish policy briefs and publications on inclusive and equitable COVID-19 policy responses (Q2 2021–Q4 
2021).

Initiate TA inception (Q2 2020). 
Engage and mobilize consultants (Q2 2020–Q3 2020). 
Undertake review of progress (Q2 2021).
